Robba and I wish you and your families a very happy new year! We are looking forward to a busy 2017. I am thankful for the opportunity to serve you, and I hope you will continue to stay in touch with me and share your thoughts and priorities through calls, emails and during my visits to your community.

I am honored and humbled to have been given another opportunity to serve Kansans in the United States Senate. I am ready to get to work to strengthen our national security, make healthcare accessible and affordable for more Americans, secure our border and make much-awaited changes to our immigration system, simplify our tax code, help local businesses thrive, and make certain Kansas farmers and ranchers can continue feeding the country and the globe.

This week‚Äôs #KansasCommonSense newsletter ‚Äì mapping out my 2016 travels, standing with #Israel, seeing Irwin Army Community Hospital at Fort Riley in action and stops in Axtell, Seneca, Bern, Logan, Harper and Ashland. Click below to subscribe or learn more.

The Obama administration made an unnecessary mistake in failing to defend one of America‚Äôs closest partners in the Middle East at the United Nations at the end of last month. Allowing the passage of such a one-sided Security Council resolution that seeks to harm Israel and ultimately pushes peace between Israel and the Palestinians further out of reach. The Senate resolution I introduced yesterday makes clear that, despite the actions of the outgoing administration, Congress and the American people still stand with #Israel. Watch my remarks on the Senate floor to learn more.

Honored to have my wife Robba, daughters Kelsey and Alex, and Alex‚Äôs husband Cole with me as I was sworn in to another six-year term in the Senate yesterday. Looking forward to the opportunities to help Kansans that the new Congress brings.

The failure to fix America‚Äôs broken immigration system puts lives at risk and justice out of reach. This week I sponsored Sarah's Law, which is named for a young woman killed nearly one year ago by a drunk driver in the country illegally. This bill would require the federal government to better prioritize its responses to individuals charged with violent crimes while in this country illegally ‚Äì correcting current policies that leave unchecked criminals free to reoffend. I will push for the bill‚Äôs passage in the 115th Congress.

In 2010 the American people were promised affordable, accessible, and quality health care that would allow them to keep the plans they liked and get more folks covered at a lower cost. As it turns out, #Obamacare has failed to live up to its promises. With a new Congress, a new year, and a new administration, we now have a tremendous opportunity to provide real, substantive reform to our healthcare system. I spoke on the Senate floor to again provide a blueprint of ideas I‚Äôve offered during my time in Congress to reform our healthcare system ‚Äì things to keep in mind as we work to improve health care for the American people.

We received another solemn reminder last week of the risks our military men and women who sign up to serve our country face in order to protect us all. Chief Warrant Officer 3 Dustin Lee Mortenson, who grew up in Olathe, and Chief Warrant Officer 2 Lucas Lowe, his fellow soldier in the Texas Army National Guard, tragically leave behind wives, children, and expected children after a helicopter crash in Texas. My sympathies go out to their loved ones. God bless our soldiers and may they rest in peace.

I caught up with and met a number of leaders in Southeast Kansas today at a Pittsburg Area Chamber of Commerce event. I shared my perspective on health care reform and how my new committee assignments and addition to the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee will help me advocate to improve Kansas transportation projects. Thank you to Chamber President Blake Benson for the invitation to provide an update on goings on at the federal level and all who shared their thoughts with me.

I was honored to have my family with me as I was sworn in to another term in the U.S. Senate this week. Serving Kansans in our nation's capital is one of the greatest privileges of my life. I took a few moments to reflect on what came before, the significance of this moment, and the responsibility Kansans have given me on their behalf.

I joined Harris Faulkner on Fox News over the weekend to discuss the upcoming Senate confirmation hearings, the administration transition and President Obama‚Äôs plan to release more than a dozen additional Guantanamo Bay (GITMO) terrorist detainees prior to inauguration day.

Today is National Law Enforcement Appreciation Day. Please share your gratitude with a member of our law enforcement community if you see one for their tireless work and willingness to put their lives on the line to protect each of us and our loved ones.
Back at the Capitol for week two of the 115th Congress ‚Äì hard at work on behalf of Kansans. Ì†ºÌ∑∫Ì†ºÌ∑∏

The federal government should be encouraging economic freedom, helping business owners innovate, and giving Kansas small businesses the freedom they need to bring jobs and growth to our state. To that end, we must have commonsense policies in place to eliminate job-killing restrictions and ensure that any new ones are appropriate. I recently sponsored the REINS Act, which puts tools in place needed to give Congress the ability to make certain that regulations promote economic success rather than impede it.

I‚Äôm pleased to hear Sen. Jeff Sessions, the President-elect‚Äôs nominee for Attorney General, recognize the important mission of the Guantanamo Bay detention facility at his confirmation hearing today. I look forward to working with the new administration to make certain that ISIS fighters and other enemy combatants who threaten the lives of Americans are detained at GITMO.

This week‚Äôs #KansasCommonSense newsletter ‚Äì laying out priorities for healthcare reform, joining my colleagues in an effort to reduce violent crime, and reintroducing legislation to hold the VA accountable. Click below to subscribe or learn more.

One month ago, the Senate unanimously passed my bipartisan bill to make certain that senior VA executives and healthcare employees convicted of a felony related to their position at the VA cannot receive the same benefits as those who honorably serve our nation‚Äôs veterans. Regrettably, the legislation did not receive a vote in the House before the close of the 114th Congress. I've reintroduced this measure and will work diligently to see it enacted by the 115th Congress and made law so it may provide some measure of justice for veterans abused under the VA‚Äôs care.

Millions of veterans across our country have been waiting far too long to receive the quality healthcare they deserve. Over the last several years, the VA‚Äôs leadership has failed to make desperately needed changes to ensure our veterans who have served and sacrificed can count on the agency sworn to serve them. I remain extremely concerned about the quality of care the VA is delivering, and I am determined to make certain Kansans can access the benefits they have earned. Despite having invited Undersecretary Shulkin to Kansas to visit our veteran healthcare facilities, I have not yet met with him during his time at the VA. He strikes me as a medical professional who cares deeply about serving veterans, and I look forward to meeting with him to hear more about his plans to reform the agency and restore veterans‚Äô faith in the VA.

Our next Secretary of Agriculture must have an unrivaled understanding of the needs and concerns of rural America. He or she must be able to support not only our farmers and ranchers in their work, but also understand the challenges of rural housing programs, the struggles of critical access hospitals, the importance of the Food and Drug Administration in setting agricultural policy, the need to expand ag exports and stay competitive in global markets, and how our next farm bill will impact our ag economy.

The vote taken in the Senate early this morning gives us the tools to repeal and replace Obamacare. Canceled policies, difficulties in identifying new plans, massive premium increases, sky-high deductibles and limited options for doctors is unfortunately the new normal for many American families. I will work with my colleagues ‚Äì Republicans and Democrats alike ‚Äì to swiftly come together, offer real reforms to lower costs and improve the quality of healthcare, and ensure there is no lapse in care. Americans deserve freedom of choice and should have access to truly affordable, quality healthcare.

I will continue serving as chairman of the Senate Commerce Subcommittee for Consumer Protection, Product Safety, Insurance and Data Security during the 115th Congress. I‚Äôm proud of our work last Congress to get two pieces of legislation passed and signed into law that will benefit consumers in Kansas and across the country ‚Äì the BOTS Act and the Consumer Review Freedom Act. I look forward to building on those consumer protections through robust congressional oversight of the agencies with an eye toward removing burdensome regulations and practices that harm innovation and consumers. Additionally, in light of recent high-profile data breaches, the need to protect our information systems has never been greater. Companies and consumers facing data security challenges are looking for policy improvements, and I will continue working to make certain our nation is prepared to combat these cyber threats.

I joined the hosts of CNBC's Squawk Box this morning to discuss jobs and American competitiveness. To grow our nation‚Äôs economy ‚Äì which is critical in creating better jobs with better wages for Americans ‚Äì we need to make the United States more attractive to businesses.

With icy weather due to hit Kansas this weekend, stay safe, stay aware and stay off the roads if possible. If you‚Äôre fortunate enough to have your good health, consider checking up on the well-being of a friend or neighbor ‚Äî it‚Äôs the little things and you never know how much it might mean to someone. Oh, and go Chiefs.

I spoke at the Kansas IDeA Network of Biomedical Research Excellence (K-INBRE) Symposium this morning. The K-INBRE system coordinates research between the National Institutes of Health (NIH) and our network of universities in Kansas, supporting faculty development and biomedical research training of students for the future. This program has brought in $56.6 million to Kansas in research funding since 2001, and has supported many Kansas science students in their career pursuits. I‚Äôm thankful to the students who took the opportunity to share their impressive research advances and discuss the potential for future research in their field including K-State Ph.D. student from Junction City JP Sibbitt (pictured with me here). I am committed to prioritizing NIH and biomedical research in the future in order to continue the United States‚Äô leadership in medical breakthroughs in the world.

I was honored to be selected to serve on the Kansas Board of Regents‚Äô KU Chancellor Search Committee and took part in meetings Friday evening. This position is critical for the future of The University of Kansas and our state, and I look forward to being part of the process. The goal is to announce a new chancellor by June.
Great to be in Lawrence this afternoon cheering on my alma mater, the Kansas Jayhawks, as they faced off with the Oklahoma State Cowboy Basketball team. 87-80 win!

Each time I visit the Martin Luther King, Jr. National Memorial overlooking the Tidal Basin and Jefferson Memorial in D.C., I am left with an even greater appreciation for the life and legacy of one of the greatest leaders in our nation's history. Dr. King's life was driven at every step by a fundamental commitment to his faith and the betterment of mankind ‚Äì we humbly pay tribute.

The Affordable Care Act was created on a straight party-line vote. Healthcare is so important it ought to have input from all members of congress, all parts of the country and all constituencies ‚Äì as compared to just a Republican plan. Many people are under the Affordable Care Act through no choice of their own. How unfair would it be to say, ‚ÄòYou have no coverage‚Äô or eliminate the coverage they were forced to take?

Speaking to more than 100 talented student researchers at the K-INBRE Symposium this weekend, I shared with them my vision for STEM in our state, which is that: We are an agricultural state, we‚Äôre an oil and gas state, we‚Äôre an airplane manufacturing state, we‚Äôre a service sector state. But what a great day it would be, a great time in our state‚Äôs history, in which we become a place with science and mathematics and engineering and research, where those students can pursue those careers and find satisfaction with employment, income and careers in our home state. Follow the link to read more.

I enjoyed visiting with an esteemed‚Äé group of U.S. Army soldiers who represent the Commanding General's Mounted Color Guard from Fort Riley and are in Washington to participate in the Inaugural Parade this Friday. I met up with these Big Red One soldiers in the United States Capitol Rotunda right at the foot of the statue that commemorates our 34th President and a man who grew up just more than 30 miles from Fort Riley itself. Over the years, Kansans have made quite a footprint in Washington, D.C., but it‚Äôs all in service to men and women like those in the Mounted Color Guard in places like Fort Riley. An honor to be with them and I know they‚Äôll represent our state in a distinguished fashion this Friday.

This week‚Äôs #KansasCommonSense newsletter ‚Äì voting to set up a critical step in repairing the damage of #Obamacare, discussing jobs and American competitiveness, and spending time over the weekend in Salina, Lawrence and Manhattan. Click below to subscribe or learn more.

At the Senate Commerce Committee Confirmation Hearing today, I emphasized the importance to the Kansas economy of trade and exports with Commerce Secretary Nominee Wilbur Ross. To view the exchange, watch below.

Military Veteran Project Founder Melissa Jarboe is an incredible advocate for veterans in Kansas and across the country. I‚Äôm pleased she could make the trip to Washington for the inauguration to represent Kansas. Welcome to Washington, Melissa!

I spoke to former Georgia Governor Sonny Perdue last night who the president-elect has nominated to lead the U.S. Department of Agriculture. The Secretary of Agriculture serves as an important voice for rural Americans whose very livelihoods often depend on the success or failure of our ag community. Agriculture doesn‚Äôt just put food on our tables ‚Äì the USDA‚Äôs role includes providing rural housing services, conducting research to expand our farmers‚Äô production capabilities, promoting American-grown products abroad, giving consumers confidence in our food supply and establishing effective safety nets for our producers. Governor Perdue‚Äôs years of experience as an advocate for Georgia farmers and ranchers, leadership in the agribusiness sector, and practice as a veterinarian give him a deep understanding of the challenges and opportunities faced by rural Americans. I look forward to hearing more from Governor Perdue about his approach and priorities.
What an opportunity for Sophie Schneider, a young Kansan from Olathe, to serve as Good Morning America's ‚Äúkid correspondent.‚Äù Something she won‚Äôt soon forget.

I pushed for answers on the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's proposed Waters of the United States (WOTUS) rule yesterday with the president-elect‚Äôs nominee to lead the EPA during a Senate confirmation hearing. Watch for his response.

This Inauguration Day, I‚Äôd like to share the story a Kansan recently shared with me about his 1993 Inauguration Day experience:  I was present for President Clinton‚Äôs first inauguration. I was not particularly excited about the outcome of that election, but I happened to be in Washington for work and thought it could be a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for a few colleagues and me. The enduring memory I have of that day was the overall atmosphere of unity and goodwill that prevailed. Though not as contentious as the election that we have just gone through, this was a tough one, too. Nonetheless, as we walked through the crowds on that January day, there was a genuine sense that all was well. When the president, whom I had not supported, spoke there were cheers all across the National Mall. But more importantly, as my colleagues and I were sitting on a bench eating sub sandwiches following the swearing in, the Marine helicopter carrying the now former President and Barbara Bush departed the Capitol one last time at tree level, low enough that you could see them in the windows. And as they passed the public all stood and waved as they waved back with smiles on their faces. I will always remember that moment in which I was truly proud to be an American and part of a system that could transfer power so peacefully and gracefully.  Let‚Äôs make today a day we‚Äôre all proud to be Americans. #inauguration2017

The peaceful transfer of power from one leader to the next is a significant principle for any democracy, and Inauguration Day serves as the litmus test for how our own is doing. I was proud to witness that principle in action again today, and I was honored to be there to represent Kansans.

Immediately following the inauguration, I encouraged President Trump to continue to prioritize serving our nation‚Äôs veterans. Unfortunately, veterans in Kansas and across the country still struggle accessing the benefits they deserve through the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA). To read my letter to the president, click the link below.

With a new president comes a new opportunity to pursue policies aimed toward economic growth and roll back regulations that stifle job creation. I‚Äôm encouraged by the new administration‚Äôs desire to scrap the overreaching and misguided 'Waters of the U.S.' (WOTUS) rule that I‚Äôve fought against since its inception. The rule has proven to be an impediment to a variety of important industries in Kansas and getting rid of it is a good first step to a more robust economy. This from the WhiteHouse.gov energy plan:    ‚ÄúFor too long, we‚Äôve been held back by burdensome regulations on our energy industry. President Trump is committed to eliminating harmful and unnecessary policies such as the Climate Action Plan and the Waters of the U.S. rule.‚Äù

On the same historic day where our great democracy peacefully transferred power from one president to another, my colleagues and I headed in from the East Front of the Capitol Building to the Senate floor and got to work confirming two of the president‚Äôs cabinet nominees: retired Gen. James Mattis for Defense Secretary and retired Gen. John Kelly for Homeland Security Secretary. Swiftly confirming both secretaries in charge of our national security is critical to keeping Kansans and Americans safe as we face threats at home and abroad. Foreign adversaries looking to challenge the United States will be rethinking their plans with General James Mattis and General John Kelly at the helm.

This morning's opening hymn was one I hadn't heard. As we prepare to start a new week, I will be reflecting on it.   "Today we are all called to be disciples of the Lord, to help set the captive free, make plow-shares out of sword, to feed the hungry, quench their thirst, make love and peace our fast, to serve the poor and homeless first, our ease and comfort last.   "Pray justice may come falling down as in a mighty stream, with righteousness in field and town to cleanse us and redeem; for God is longing to restore an earth where conflicts cease, a world that was created for a harmony of peace." ‚ÄîH. Kenn Carmichael, 1985

My fellow Kansan Ajit Pai is an excellent choice to lead the FCC. I have worked with him over the years through my role on the Senate Commerce Committee, traveled with him throughout our state, and gotten to know him on a personal level. I know him to be a capable and talented leader and one of the smartest people I have ever met when it comes to public policy. Ajit understands the importance of quality access to broadband and wireless connectivity, and I believe growing up in Kansas makes him uniquely qualified to advocate for rural America. I look forward to continuing to work with him to make certain we can improve connectivity and bring critical updates not only to our homes and businesses but also to our hospitals and schools.

Today the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO) released its deficit projection and economic outlook for the coming decade. The CBO report projects our nation‚Äôs debt and deficits to continue to rise toward levels dangerous to the fiscal health of our economy. Within the decade, debt held by the public will rise to nearly 90 percent of GDP, the highest level since 1947. In all, the national debt will grow to more than three times the size of our entire economy.    The report makes it abundantly clear that Congress must not put off the difficult decisions Americans elected us to make. With a national debt approaching $20 trillion, it is the next generation who will be punished if we do not confront our fiscal challenges. If we fail to act, we will not only stifle job creation and economic growth, but threaten the ability of future generations to pursue the American Dream.

I‚Äôm accepting applications for summer 2017 internships in Kansas and the nation‚Äôs capital. An internship in my office provides a unique opportunity to work closely with Senate staff on behalf of Kansans.  If you or someone you know may be interested, please visit my website or check out this video to learn more. The deadline is Friday, February 17.

I called on the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service today to request that they formally extend their lesser prairie chicken status review comment period. Kansans are concerned with conserving the lesser prairie chicken and are interested in providing comments based on the most up-to-date information regarding the bird‚Äôs population and habitat area. Closing the comment period now will exclude some of the most pertinent information, like the Western Association of Fish and Wildlife Agencies‚Äô annual progress report, which hasn‚Äôt yet been released. Read my full letter here.

Today I was selected to serve as chairman of the Senate Military Construction and Veterans Affairs Subcommittee, which addresses Department of Defense investments in infrastructure, the quality of life for military families, and also makes improvements at the Department of Veterans Affairs to better serve our nation‚Äôs veterans. This role will help me make certain our nation is following through on its commitments made to our military men and women before and after their service.   In my expanded role, I wasted no time meeting with the president‚Äôs nominee to lead the Department of Veterans Affairs, Dr. David Shulkin. Dr. Shulkin and I discussed the desperately needed changes that must take place at the VA to make the agency worthy of every single veteran it is sworn to serve. The opportunity Dr. Shulkin could have to make a difference in the lives of veterans cannot be overstated, and I look forward to continuing the dialogue with him about how to reform the VA and restore veterans‚Äô trust in the agency created to serve them.

Welcomed a group of middle school students from St. John Catholic School in Lawrence yesterday, where they braved the weather to meet with me on the steps of the Capitol. They asked thoughtful questions about early education and shared some of their past experiences during their annual trips to Washington, D.C.

The new administration is taking long overdue action to remove corrupt employees from the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA). I encouraged President Trump to increase accountability at the VA last week, and I am encouraged that his administration shares this priority. The majority of VA employees are hardworking individuals and committed to serving our nations veterans, but bad actors who do not share in that commitment should not be allowed to benefit from taxpayer dollars.

This week‚Äôs #KansasCommonSense newsletter ‚Äì A peaceful transfer of power, confirming qualified Defense and Homeland Security secretaries and learning more about the approaches of various cabinet nominees.

Overregulation is among the greatest threats to the economy of rural America, and my roles on the U.S. Committee on Environment and Public Works and Senate Agriculture Appropriations Subcommittee will better position me to advocate for family farmers and ranchers and work to eliminate burdensome regulations that threaten the future of rural America. Click below to learn more.

I visited Wellington this week to tour GKN Aerospace Precision MCHNG (GKN) which has about 220 employees and continues to be one of the largest employers in Sumner County. GKN has the great responsibility of producing the section 41 floor module for Boeing's new 787 Dreamliner. As co-chair of the Senate Aerospace Caucus, I take pride in our local aerospace manufacturers and the vital part they play in our Kansas economy. Thanks to Operations Manager Wes Lough, Site Leader Todd Gardner, and Vice President and General Manager Brian DeCamp for attending and touring with me.   I was also in Kiowa for a stop at Kiowa District Healthcare Hospital (KDH) to learn more about their efforts to provide quality care to patients. Kiowa has an impressive 29-bed Critical Access Hospital serving the community since 1951. KDH provides a wide range of services, including imaging and laboratory services, physical, occupational and speech therapy and surgery. We discussed healthcare access in rural areas and the VA's Choice program. Barber County is fortunate to have this state of the art hospital which is less than three years old. Thank you to CFO Janell Goodno for coordinating my visit and Kiowa Mayor Brandon Farney, Kiowa Chamber President Janet Robinson and KDH board members for joining us.

Here‚Äôs something that happened today that we can all celebrate: Rachel Mast, a young Olathe resident, opened the first ABLE account in Kansas. ABLE accounts are designed to help provide increased financial stability and independence for Americans with disabilities. I first met Rachel back in 2012 when she came to Washington, D.C., with her mother to tell me about the ABLE Act. She won me over with her charisma and a desire for something so central to the American Dream ‚Äì to be able to save and make her own way through life. I‚Äôm thrilled that five years after that first meeting and more than a year after the legislation I helped lead was signed into law, Rachel‚Äôs hard work and advocacy paid off and now young people across the country in similar situations will have an improved opportunity to experience a full and satisfying life ‚Äì to live, learn, work and follow their dreams.

I visited the newly relocated Airbus Engineering Center at the Wichita State University (WSU) Innovation Campus this week to see the new facility firsthand. Nearly 15 years ago, the talent pool of aviation experts who are among the brightest in the world drew Airbus to Wichita to build its first U.S.-based engineering center. Airbus is now collaborating with WSU‚Äôs engineering and business schools, National Institute for Aviation Research, Wichita State University (NIAR) and similar organizations also located within the Innovation Campus with the goal of producing the next generation of aviation experts by providing students experiential employment opportunities. I toured the Engineering Center and the Innovation Campus GoCreate Maker Space, which provides students and workers access to the technology and services that help facilitate product development. Thank you to John O‚ÄôLeary for leading my tour and for your leadership at Airbus Engineering. Thank you also to President John Bardo for providing the vision and drive necessary in order to make the WSU Innovation Campus a reality.

I was the guest speaker at today‚Äôs breakfast meeting of the Hutchinson Ambucs Club where I had the chance to visit with those in attendance about the new administration, cabinet nominations and the confirmation process and working to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act. We also talked about jobs and economic growth, reining in our national debt, and the importance of caring for our veterans. Thank you to club president Dorinda Simmons and Kathy Hanks for the kind invitation and to all club members for their dedication to creating mobility and independence for people with disabilities. I was glad to see State Senator Ed Berger, former State Senator Dave Kerr and Judge Patty Macke Dick in attendance.

I was in Hays today and joined a small group of community members for a roundtable discussion at the Fort Hays State University (FHSU) Foundation. The conversation touched on many important topics including the new administration and congress and their concerns on the issues they care most about and the future of our country, such as ensuring Kansas kids have the opportunities to pursue their dreams in our state. It was a helpful opportunity to share with the group my legislative priorities for 2017, as well as get their feedback on what they‚Äôd like to see accomplished this year. I appreciated visiting with everyone. Thank you to the FHSU Foundation for your hospitality and to Chartwell‚Äôs Dining Service for providing the delicious lunch.

Today the 44th Annual March for Life brought hundreds of thousands of men and women of all backgrounds from Kansas and across the country to Washington to march for the fundamental right to life. Their determination to march year after year, often in bitterly cold Washington winters, highlights the determination of this movement. As we kick off a new session of Congress, I am joining my colleagues in pursuing several pieces of legislation to protect innocent children, the American taxpayers and medical providers. #MarchforLife2017

I made a couple stops in Southeast Kansas this week in Parsons and Fredonia. In Parsons, I attended Rotary Club and got to share the news that the local aerospace manufacturing supplier Ducommun, Inc., was awarded a multi-million dollar contract with Airbus, which should create more than 80 jobs in the Parsons community and provide a great economic boost to the area. Additionally, I had the chance to discuss the president‚Äôs designation of Parsons native Ajit Pai as acting Chairman of the Federal Communications Commission (FCC). Being from Parsons, Ajit understands the importance of quality access to broadband and wireless connectivity, and I look forward to continuing to work with him to make certain we can improve connectivity and bring critical updates not only to our homes and businesses, but also to our hospitals and schools.   In Fredonia, I visited Fredonia High School (Kansas) where FHS Principal Jamie Camacho and a group of student leaders gave me a tour of their school. They had thoughtful insight into the importance of technical education programs and talked to me about their participation in the SkillsUSA program, where they build and race pedal cars. My thanks for the warm hospitality I was shown. These students were a demonstration of the value of strong public education and gave me inspiration about the future of our state and nation.

Communities across our state are strengthened by the Kansans who participate in civic clubs. Lions Clubs work to make Kansas communities strong and I have been an active member over the last 40 years of the Hays Lions Club and Hill City Lion's Club. I was the keynote speaker at a meeting of the statewide clubs this afternoon and had a great discussion with members. The Lions club motto is ‚ÄúWe Serve,‚Äù and the many Lions serving across Kansas exemplify this selfless spirit. Thanks to Lions Clubs International Chancellor Bob Corlew for joining us on Saturday and for the peace poster plaque and centennial silver dollar I received from the group.    I then headed to the 16th Annual Kansas Mission of Mercy Dental Clinic. In just two days, these dentists voluntarily serve roughly 1,200  Kansans providing cleanings, fillings, root canals and more at zero cost. For some, a dental check-up means the one day per year you get told to floss more frequently, but a significant number of Kansans don‚Äôt receive annual dental care at all and an event like this weekend‚Äôs is a huge help in improving their dental and overall health. Each year the event is put on by the Kansas Dental Charitable Foundation and this year‚Äôs co-chairs were Drs. Ryan Grieves and Randy Davis. Thanks to the dentists who were out in force to help keep Kansans healthy and grins wide.

Kansans have historically carried on the pioneering tradition of our state‚Äôs founders. We value community-mindedness, hard work and self-determination. It is the outlook that guided the millions of homesteaders and railroad workers who came from different regions to join together and build up a new place to call home. These traits and that desire to be independent live on today and empower us to set an example for the rest of the country that, despite our disagreements, we can work together to rise above disputes and come together to make positive improvements to our communities. In our pursuit of a better tomorrow, we must not allow ourselves to grow pessimistic about setbacks. This idea is underscored by our state‚Äôs motto, ‚ÄúTo the Stars through difficulty.‚Äù We set our sights high and work doggedly to meet the challenge. It is the Kansas way.  Let‚Äôs guide the way of our nation. Let‚Äôs be the example and always look for the best in each other. Our state‚Äôs 157th year holds tremendous promise, and I hope we realize that promise by carrying on our founders‚Äô values and working together for the good of the state and nation. I‚Äôm grateful to again have the opportunity to serve in the United States Senate on your behalf. I take the blessing of being a Kansan to heart ‚Äì each day, I hope to bring our home state‚Äôs sense of hard work, dedication to service and innate respect for our neighbors to my work in Washington, D.C.  I want to thank the vocal students at Salina High School South under the direction of Eddie Creer Jr. for the beautiful rendition of "Home on the Range" featured in this video.

Keeping Americans safe should be our federal government's top priority. Strengthening our immigration system is critical to that end, and it‚Äôs common sense to have appropriate vetting procedures in place for individuals wishing to travel to our country. While I support thorough vetting, I do not support restricting the rights of U.S. citizens and lawful permanent residents. Furthermore, far-reaching national security policy should always be devised in consultation with Congress and relevant government agencies.

This chairmanship gives me the opportunity to address U.S. Department of Defense (DoD) investments in infrastructure, the quality of life for military families, and also to make improvements at the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs to better serve our nation‚Äôs veterans. I take seriously my role in being a responsible steward of taxpayer dollars. I will work to make certain funding is prioritized in order to make good on our the pledge we make to our servicemembers and veterans, and to support critical infrastructure at home and abroad vital to keeping Kansans and Americans safe.

Being from a rural Kansas town myself, I enjoyed this NPR All Things Considered profile of Independence, Kansas. It‚Äôs a good illustration of some of the daily routines, struggles and rewards of life in small-town USA. I particularly appreciate this passage on how these women in Independence discuss politics with civility and mindfulness of their neighbors:  ‚ÄúI find Kays and her early morning women's walking group chatting over cups of coffee at Ane Mae's coffee shop. They tell me that in a town like this, you tread carefully when talking politics.  "We do express our opinions, but then we kind of back away politely," Sarah Wilson begins. "We are Kansas polite! We are a Kansas polite community!" adds Kays.  "Good ol' Midwest," Sheri Hesse chimes in.  "It's kind of like, 'Yes, I feel this way, but I understand how you feel.' Last night, the Senate rejected the Better Care Reconciliation Act (BCRA) with a vote of 43-57. As I indicated last week, the BCRA missed the mark for Kansans and did not have my support. Not only does this bill fail to adequately repeal Obamacare, but it also does nothing to address the rising costs of healthcare, provide for the needs of the most vulnerable, such as those in the disability and elderly communities, or strengthen the ability of rural hospitals in Kansas to keep their doors open.
